title: ISO 29148 Requirements Rally
theme: Coordinate requirements for a multi-city mobility control platform
overview:
You are supporting three city councils that merged their transit control rooms. The new platform must consolidate telemetry, crew rosters, and disruption workflows without breaking existing contracts. This rally guides the cohort through ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148 activities so every requirement remains justified, testable, and traceable.

Students will collect context-of-use evidence, structure stakeholder needs, write specification fragments, and close with validation assets that connect directly to ISO 29148 clauses.

labs.title: Stakeholder Discovery Studio
labs.summary: Elicit context-of-use data, constraints, and stakeholder priorities (ISO 29148 clauses 5-6).

labs.title: Specification Architecture Workshop
labs.summary: Transform needs into structured requirement statements and trace them to solution elements (clauses 7-9).

labs.title: Validation & Traceability Sprint
labs.summary: Link acceptance criteria, verification methods, and change control (clauses 10-11).

resources: Annex G – Content of requirements specification
UFV facilitation note: always tie acceptance criteria back to stakeholder intent
completionMessage: Share the completed traceability deck with the city councils and log pending clarifications before sprint planning.

challenges.title: Stakeholder Immersion Brief
challenges.narrative: The three municipalities run different dispatch tools. Before you phrase any requirement, ISO 29148 insists on capturing context-of-use, operational constraints, and stakeholder intent.
objectives: Capture environment, user, and equipment factors per clause 6.4
Document stakeholder goals with source attribution
Surface conflicting constraints that must be negotiated later

tasks.content: Review the joint operations transcript and highlight every mention of user types, locations, and performance thresholds.
tasks.helper: Color-code environment, user, and equipment statements so you can reference them quickly.

resources.label: ISO 29148 clause 6.4 summary
resources.note: Use any authorized PDF excerpt you already have access to.

tasks.instruction: Populate the stakeholder alignment brief. Include persona, motivation, authority level, and must-not-fail scenario for at least four roles.
tasks.example: Transit Commander – needs a consolidated disruption queue to reassign crews within 8 minutes.
checklist: List the mission outcome they guard

tasks.instruction: Interview the instructor role-playing the Maintenance Lead to understand seasonal constraints and safety certifications.
tasks.helper: Ask for concrete numbers (e.g., crew count, outage tolerance) so future requirements can inherit them verbatim.

tasks.instruction: Draft a one-page immersion brief summarizing the context-of-use and the top three stakeholder risks. Attach evidence references.
tasks.helper: Use ISO 29148 Table 9 to justify why each risk matters to the specification scope.

quizzes.question: Which ISO 29148 artifact records environment, user, and equipment characteristics before drafting requirements?
quizzes.rationale: Clause 6.4 mandates documenting the context of use to keep requirements grounded in reality.

quizzes.question: Why must each stakeholder goal cite a source per ISO 29148?
choices: To preserve traceability back to the stakeholder
quizzes.rationale: Traceability begins at the source; without attribution you cannot justify the requirement downstream.

challenges.nextStepCue: Share the immersion brief with the cohort and highlight any conflicting stakeholder expectations before moving on.

challenges.title: Requirement Quality Board
challenges.narrative: Raw notes flood the team. ISO 29148 Annex D prescribes quality characteristics that every individual requirement must satisfy before entering the baseline.
objectives: Classify statements as needs, constraints, or design ideas
Rewrite ambiguous notes into ISO 29148-compliant requirement text
Score each requirement against quality attributes

tasks.content: Sort yesterday's sticky notes into Must Describe Need, Must Describe Constraint, or Design Suggestion.
tasks.helper: If a note prescribes UI elements, park it in Design Suggestion until the specification team confirms.

tasks.instruction: Rewrite at least six needs into atomic requirement statements using the ISO 29148 structure (condition, subject, action, constraint).
tasks.example: When disruption severity equals red, the system shall lock the crew roster until a commander approves changes.
tasks.helper: Read each sentence aloud; if you need to say 'and', split it.

tasks.instruction: For each rewritten requirement, rate it against the quality checklist (necessary, unambiguous, complete, singular, feasible, verifiable).
Prepare a backlog excerpt with the top five requirements, their quality scores, and open questions.
tasks.helper: Flag any statement that still contains TBD data so the instructor can guide follow-up elicitation.

quizzes.question: Which trait proves a requirement is singular per ISO 29148 Annex D?
choices: It references more than one stakeholder
It is written in passive voice
quizzes.rationale: Singular requirements describe a single capability or quality so verification remains straightforward.

quizzes.question: A note reads 'Provide real-time dashboards with nice maps.' What is the best first action?
choices: Classify it as a design suggestion and elicit the underlying need
Convert it into a test case
quizzes.rationale: You must separate the expressed design from the underlying requirement before rewriting it.

challenges.nextStepCue: Once the board agrees on the top requirements, move into specification structuring.

challenges.title: Specification Story Map
challenges.narrative: The councils expect to see how stakeholder needs flow into specification sections required by ISO 29148 clause 9.
objectives: Identify derived requirements triggered by constraints
Draft narrative hooks for each section

tasks.content: Review the specification outline mandated by the PMO (introduction, referenced documents, interface requirements, performance, verification).

tasks.instruction: Create a story map that places each validated requirement into its target section and notes traceability back to stakeholders.
tasks.helper: Use swimlanes for stakeholder groups so conflicts surface visually.

tasks.instruction: Consult the instructor acting as Legal Counsel to capture regulatory clauses that must appear in the specification.
tasks.example: Data retention policies for cross-city incident logs

tasks.instruction: Write opening paragraphs for two priority sections, referencing ISO 29148 clause numbers and stakeholder sources.
tasks.helper: Show how each paragraph transitions into measurable requirements; avoid promising design.

quizzes.question: Where should interface dependencies be documented per ISO 29148 clause 9?
choices: Within the context of use section
In the annex with terms and acronyms
quizzes.rationale: Clause 9 requires dedicated interface requirement content so downstream teams can plan integrations.

quizzes.question: When deriving requirements from legal constraints you should first…
choices: Assess the constraint category and cite its origin
Convert it directly into test steps
Drop it unless a user asked
quizzes.rationale: Traceability demands linking each derived requirement to its source, such as a regulation or policy.

challenges.nextStepCue: Confirm the story map with the PMO before locking traceability IDs.

challenges.title: Traceability Grid & Change Impact
challenges.narrative: The councils worry about scope creep. ISO 29148 clause 7.2.5 emphasizes maintaining bidirectional traceability and assessing change impact.
objectives: Assign unique identifiers to each requirement
Simulate a change request and evaluate impact

tasks.instruction: Populate the traceability matrix with stakeholder IDs, requirement IDs, and verification references.
tasks.helper: Follow the ID convention CITY-<lab>-<number> to keep context obvious.

tasks.instruction: Select one requirement and draft three verification methods (analysis, test, inspection) with pass/fail criteria.
tasks.example: Analysis – confirm algorithm handles 5k concurrent events with < 3s response

tasks.instruction: Process a hypothetical change request: 'Increase crew reassignment window from 8 to 12 minutes.' Capture impact across interfaces, verification, and stakeholders.
tasks.helper: Note whether new constraints violate previously agreed KPIs.

tasks.instruction: Present the traceability snapshot and change impact summary to the instructor.
tasks.helper: Emphasize which artifacts must be updated when the change is approved.

quizzes.question: Which statement best describes bidirectional traceability?
choices: Requirements link only to design elements
Every requirement can be traced to its source and to its verification evidence
quizzes.rationale: ISO 29148 insists on bidirectional links between sources, requirements, and verification artifacts.

quizzes.question: When evaluating a change request, which factor comes first?
choices: Impact on requirement identifiers and verification plans
quizzes.rationale: Impact analysis starts with the affected requirements and their verification commitments.

challenges.nextStepCue: Lock the traceability IDs before entering validation planning.

challenges.title: Validation & Acceptance Canvas
challenges.narrative: Councils expect a concrete validation plan demonstrating each requirement's acceptance evidence per clause 10.
objectives: Select validation techniques per requirement category
Define completion messaging for the client review

tasks.content: Study the verification references captured earlier and map them to ISO 29148 validation activities.
tasks.helper: Note where stakeholder witnessing is required to close the loop.

tasks.instruction: Draft acceptance criteria for three requirements, listing metric, benchmark, evidence owner, and validation method.
Write validation session notes describing how the instructor (as client) will sign off each criterion.
tasks.helper: Use active verbs (witnesses, inspects, tests) so responsibilities are clear.

tasks.instruction: Produce a closing message for the councils summarizing readiness, remaining risks, and next review date.
tasks.helper: Reference ISO 29148 clause 10.2 to justify why each validation activity completes the requirement life cycle.

quizzes.question: Which element must every acceptance criterion include per ISO 29148?
quizzes.rationale: Validation depends on measurable criteria that confirm whether the requirement is satisfied.

quizzes.question: Validation differs from verification because it…
choices: Confirms the solution meets stakeholder intent and operational need
quizzes.rationale: Validation demonstrates that implemented capabilities satisfy stakeholder intent, not just technical specs.

challenges.nextStepCue: Archive the acceptance pack and schedule the multi-city sign-off meeting.
